Award.AwardTitle: Meeting: Inaugural Neuroimaging Workshop on the Dynamic Social Brain (October 22-23, 2015)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A key challenge in the study of the human brain resides not only in determining how psychological states and processes map onto patterns of brain activity but how this activity is modulated by shared representations, social compositions, and social behaviors. When the term "social neuroscience" was introduced in 1992 and characterized as the study of the transduction pathways between the various biological and social levels of organization, the dominant perspective for examining the brain was the solitary computer. Since 1992, it has also become essential to consider theoretically and empirically how thinking brains think about other thinking brains, a core concept in social neuroscience. The past 25 years have seen not only the acceptance of the field of social neuroscience, but also its tremendous growth as an integrative and interdisciplinary field towards medical neuroscience, as several neuroimaging procedures were burgeoning, and human lesion studies, comparative research, and animal models began to focus more on the biological basis of social structures and their effects on mental and physical health. The growth of social neuroscience has been fueled by research the expansion of these methods, and by the development of analytic tools for studying the dynamic neural aspects of the social brain in health and disease. With such a fast growth, there is a crucial need for neuroscientists to stay up-to-date on the available neuroimaging methods and cutting-edge analytic tools to study the social brain. Dr. Stephanie Cacioppo at the University of Chicago Pritzker School of Medicine will lead the first neuroimaging workshop on the dynamic social brain to address this need by focusing on the most important neuroimaging technique used by social neuroscientists, namely, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).

This workshop will offer attendees both a theoretical and a practical background to provide attendees with a unique opportunity to learn more about the cutting-edge neuroimaging methods and analytic tools currently available for rigorous investigation of the social brain. The internationally renown speakers in this year's neuroimaging workshop meeting will illustrate the value of comparative research and will stimulate discussions among attendees regarding the importance of opening new dialogues between researchers and clinicians. Lectures will be intertwined with 45-minute long sessions dedicated to promote more discussion on building more meaningful bridges between researchers pertaining to social neuroscience and its implications for society at large. This workshop aims to raise awareness on the intimate relationship between theory and methods; to promote the discussion on a set of considerations to guide the interpretation or understanding of data from neuroimaging studies; to highlight the importance of using converging methods to dissect the social brain; to identify common themes in the neural mechanisms of social behavior; and to promote discussion on building more meaningful bridges between researchers and clinicians and between animal and human researchers pertaining to social neuroscience and its implications for society at large. This workshop is expected to have academic and societal impact by fostering interdisciplinary and international interactions and potential collaboration among a tremendous diversity of talented young researchers at various career stages, from different disciplines, and from historically under-represented groups. By bringing students, fellows, and faculty together from various departments to learn about and work on neuroimaging to address questions about brain function from each of their perspectives, they will learn about the inherently interdisciplinary nature of the enterprise and the importance of interdisciplinary research teams to address their individual questions. The final outcome of this workshop will be the development of large-scale, high quality, and cross-cutting collaborative project proposals possibly international, from interdisciplinary scientific teams in neuroimaging composed of researchers and clinicians studying animal and human social behaviors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award provided travel awards for students and young investigators to attend the first Chicago Neuroimaging Workshop (CNW) on the Social Brain. This included talented under-represented undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows and/or early career faculty who might not have adequate resources to attend the workshop. Women, minorities, and young investigators from U.S. Institutions were explicitly encouraged to apply for these travel awards. We received a total of 64 applications from diverse origins, ethnicities, and genders. Out of these 64 applications, 97% came from the United States, 1.5% from India, and 1.5% from the United Kingdom. Only applications from the United States were considered for the NSF travel award. Among the US applications, 64.06% came from women, while 35.94% came from men. Only 51 out of these 64 applicants met our selection criteria. The persons who met our selection criteria described their race/ethnicity as follows: 1 African American, 5 Latino/Hispanic, 16 White/Caucasian, 5 Asian, and 24 n/a. Among them, 72.55% were women and 27.45% were men. Forty-three percent (43%) of the NSF award recipients were women.

The inaugural CNW workshop was held as a post-satellite meeting of the Annual Meetings of the Society for Social Neuroscience (S4SN) and the Society for Neuroscience (SfN). The response to this workshop was also excellent. More than 140 individuals sought to attend the workshop. To ensure enough time for discussions and interactions among participants and presenters, the workshop only accepted a limited number of participants (N = 70). Moreover, the CNW program and selection decisions were designed to ensure a balance across gender, topics, and career stage and to provide time and opportunities for discussions and interactions among students and faculty participants. More than half (70%) of the participants came from institutions in the United States (19% from the University of Chicago, 51% from other U.S. Universities), and 30% came from universities outside the U.S. Half (50%) of the participants were women. All participants expressed an interest in learning more about the cutting-edge advances in neuroimaging and in methods to investigate the human connectome, independently of their level of expertise in fMRI. A diverse audience composed the CNW meeting. The level of fMRI expertise varied from no experience (12%) to beginner (50%), intermediate (30%), and to advanced level (8%). This workshop offered attendees both a theoretical and a practical background and provided them with a unique opportunity to learn more about the cutting-edge neuroimaging methods and analytic tools currently available for rigorous investigation of the social brain. The internationally renowned speakers (Dr. Grafton; Dr. Sporns; Dr. Bassett; Dr. Flandin; Dr. Cacioppo, and Mr. Monteleone) in this neuroimaging meeting illustrated the value of comparative research and stimulated discussions among attendees regarding the importance of opening new dialogues between researchers and clinicians. Each lecture was followed by a 45-minute Q&A session – a unique format dedicated to promote more discussion on building more meaningful bridges between researchers pertaining to social neuroscience and its implications for society at large. An online post-meeting survey was performed on Survey Monkey. A total of 41 participants completed the survey. Among the respondents, 97.44% attended both days of the CNW. The responses to the survey were extremely positive, with 78.2% rating the presentations as “excellent”.

Broader Impacts: By bringing students, fellows, and faculty together from various departments, various universities, and various countries, this workshop is expected to have academic and societal impact by fostering interdisciplinary and international interactions and potential collaboration among a tremendous diversity of talented young researchers at various career stages, from different disciplines, and from historically under-represented groups. The NSF awards also provided a boost to the careers of budding scientists at a time when encouragement and support is most needed. The long-term outcome of this workshop will be the development of large-scale, high quality, and cross-cutting collaborative project proposals possibly international, from interdisciplinary scientific teams in neuroimaging composed of researchers and clinicians studying animal and human social behaviors from various departments and/or multiple Universities within the U.S. and beyond. Finally, based on the success of this first meeting, a second meeting was organized on November 10, 2016 as a pre-meeting of the annual meeting of S4SN and SfN. This meeting was very successful.
